qas.question: What article of clothing could generally be found on a male Roman?
What garment was worn by male gendered adults to convey their status as a citizen of Rome?
What was typically worn after the loss of a loved one in the Roman Republic?
Which official would wear a garment containing broad red striping?
How did a womans garment typically vary from a mans in the Roman Republic?

context: Men typically wore <a0_0>a toga<a0_0/>, and women a stola. The woman's stola differed in looks from a toga, and was <a4_0>usually brightly coloured<a4_0/>. The cloth and the dress distinguished one class of people from the other class. The tunic worn by plebeians, or common people, like shepherds and slaves, was made from coarse and dark material, whereas the tunic worn by patricians was of linen or white wool. A knight or magistrate would wear an augusticlavus, a tunic bearing small purple studs. <a3_0>Senators<a3_0/> wore tunics with broad red stripes, called tunica laticlavia. Military tunics were shorter than the ones worn by civilians. Boys, up until the festival of Liberalia, wore the toga praetexta, which was a toga with a crimson or purple border. The <a1_0>toga virilis<a1_0/>, (or toga pura) was worn by men over the age of 16 to signify their citizenship in Rome. The toga picta was worn by triumphant generals and had embroidery of their skill on the battlefield. <a2_0>The toga pulla<a2_0/> was worn when in mourning.[citation needed]
